author: tersec
content: One piece of messaging that I've not seen that much delivered in a concerted way is quantifying the actual (not very large) losses of missing an attestation or two, and just working through some expected-value calculations of that even a low likelihood of slashing due to misconfiguration under many assumption sets results in less expected profit than a simpler configuration which misses a few attestations.

author: tersec
content:
There are more technical writeups aimed at people comparing validator performance metrics or who want to look at exactly how Altair changed the reward schemes, but in terms of providing baseline expectations for people running validators, maybe they're around, but not sure I've seen as much targeted to that audience.

(Staking pools, who know all this already and make the bet anyway, are a different question.)

author: ajsutton
content: I've found just saying "inactivity penalties are small but a slashing is forever" tends to hold a lot of weight currently.  It will become less so as withdrawals get closer but the biggest penalty for slashing at the moment is having the remaining ETH locked and unproductive indefinitely.

author: ajsutton
content: But the biggest challenge seems to be getting people to understand that there's a difference between inactivity penalty and slashing.  So often people think they're getting slashed when they miss an attestation.
